lord tammerlain

A few analytical methods you might be able to use 
 
 density. with the knowledge of the density of butyl acetate, acetic acid, and water, the difference between the expected and analytical result should provide a rough indicator
 
 pH. Should allow you to determine roughly the amount of acetic acid.
 
 http://www.scielo.br/pdf/bjce/v19n2/10666.pdf
 
 is a site that gives some of the information you may need
 
 
 Overall I would try to find a titration method to determing butyl acetate.
 
 Distallation using boiling points to collect the various fractions.

I don't think the distillation would work. Assuming that everything is in equalibrium, if you boil off the butanol then the butyl acetate would just dissacociate, giving you more butanol, wouldn't it?

 Not having checked the stability of butyl acetate, I expect that it would be stable enough to be distilled, with only minor losses in yield. Perhaps crystalization purification would be more appropriate, or an extraction based on solubility.

I used to be able to do the math, it has been a while and I would have to go through some old text books. I have done some reaction chemistry, at the bench scale and usually after the reaction is complete the resultant chemicals are fairly stable.

 
 The easisest method would be to measure the acid number of acetic acid using a standard titrant, such as 1N NaOH, to a phenolphthalein endpoint. 
 
 The amount of acetic acid (HAC) initially is equivalent to the moles of NaOH consumed.
 
 HAC + NaOH --------< NaAC + H2O
 
 You calculate the amount of BuAC by calculating the # of moles of HAC remaining after your reaction.
 
 Moles BuAC = Moles HAC (initial) - Moles HAC (final) =
 moles of NaOH(initial) - moles of NaOH(final), determined during your titration of reactant mixture and finished product mixture.
